_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Fruit and Vegetable Canning, Pickling, and Drying

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chelan Fruit Cooperative's, (hereafter referred to as CFC) accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of CFC to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.



Anhydrous ammonia is used on-site.  Ammonia considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance List (CAS #7664-41-7).



CFC refrigeration personnel do not respond to ammonia releases, but have received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, in addition to training specifically for ammonia.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees receive training on this plan. In the case of a large release of ammonia, Okanogan County Fire Department #8 would be called.  The fire dept would be responsible for providing Hazmat trained professionals.  CFC's refrigeration department receives on-going training on their responsibilities in response to a release of ammonia.  They will immediately exit the facility, bringing along any personnel they come in contact with, and report to the appropriate evacuation area. They will not re-enter the facility for any reason until the Hazmat team has given the all clear notice.



There is approximately 21,611 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the Okanogan facility. The largest vessel is located in Engine Room C and potentially could release 4,772 pounds of product.   



CFC uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  



CFC complies with:



* OSHA's and Washington State's process safety management rules.

* Washington State's safety regulations.

* IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) standards for good work practices.



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to standar

ds and local codes at the time of installation.  Piping and equipment is secured and protected; engine room doors are tight fitting, open outward and are generally kept closed.  Other safety systems CFC utilizes include:



* Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely

* Suction trap hi-level float

* High discharge pressure shut down

* Low suction pressure shut down

* High discharge temperature shut down

* Oil pressure failure shut down

* High amperes shut down

* Automatic timer to prevent short cycling via computer controls

* Oil filters plugged shut down

* 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

* 150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations



Operating Procedures and checklists have been prepared by CFC to be used by employees performing operational functions. Procedures are kept in the refrigeration office.  These procedures include: 



* Pre-start up procedures

* Routine operations

* Maintenance

* Response to major and minor releases

* emergency action plan



At CFC, the ammonia is used in a closed system, so the threat of ammonia mixing with an incompatible material is minimal.  It is important to keep potential incompatible materials away from areas that have the highest potential of a release, such as pressure relief devices.   Ammonia is stable and hazardous polymerization will not occur.
